L1.brief_rationale: The most fundamental concept in ethics, universally recognized as the distinction between right and wrong conduct.
A core social and ethical value concerning fairness, equity, and rightful treatment, familiar to all cultures.
Universally recognized entitlements of all persons, foundational to contemporary moral and political discourse.
A basic moral virtue universally understood as truthfulness and avoidance of deception.
Widely recognized moral sentiment involving empathy and concern for the suffering of others.
An intuitive moral concept involving equal and impartial treatment, understood by all age groups and cultures.
The most basic moral polarity, universally present across religious, cultural, and philosophical traditions.
The inner moral sense familiar to everyday discourse, guiding individuals in distinguishing right from wrong.
A universally recognized moral quality of excellence in character, central to common moral language.
Widely understood entitlements that constrain how individuals may be treated, foundational to moral and legal reasoning.
A common moral concept referring to obligations one is bound to fulfill, recognized in everyday and professional contexts.
The intuitive moral baseline — causing harm is broadly recognized as wrong — underpinning most ethical systems.
A foundational value in ethics and political philosophy, universally understood as treating persons the same under shared rules.

L2.brief_rationale: The most widely taught consequentialist theory, holding that the right action maximizes overall well-being or utility.
Kant's supreme principle of morality — act only on maxims you could will to be universal laws — central to deontological ethics.
An Aristotelian approach focusing on character and human flourishing rather than rules or consequences, taught in introductory ethics courses.
The family of theories holding that the morality of an action depends on its conformity to rules or duties, not outcomes.
The view that the rightness of an action is determined solely by its consequences, encompassing utilitarianism and related theories.
The foundational political-ethical idea that moral and political obligations derive from agreement among individuals, associated with Hobbes, Locke, and Rousseau.
The canonical ethical thought experiment used to probe intuitions about the permissibility of causing harm to prevent greater harm.
The view that moral judgments are relative to cultural or individual standards rather than universal, a standard topic in introductory ethics.
The long-standing tradition holding that morality is grounded in nature or reason and discoverable through rational inquiry.
The view that pleasure is the highest good and proper aim of action, foundational to utilitarian and Epicurean thought.
The metaethical position that objective moral facts exist independently of minds or cultures, a core topic in metaethics courses.
The branch of ethics that applies moral principles to specific practical domains such as medicine, law, and business.

The principle of treating others as one wishes to be treated, present across virtually all ethical and religious traditions and familiar to philosophy students as a bridge to formal reciprocity arguments.

L3.brief_rationale: The position that certain moral truths apply to all persons at all times, standing in direct contrast to moral relativism and requiring substantive engagement with metaethics.
The distinction between evaluating individual acts by their consequences versus evaluating rules whose general adoption maximizes utility — a key internal debate within consequentialism.
The principle that an action causing harm as a side effect of achieving a good outcome may be permissible under specified conditions, central to medical ethics and just war theory.
The metaethical view that basic moral truths are self-evident and known through direct intuition, associated with G.E. Moore and W.D. Ross.
J.L. Mackie's metaethical view that moral claims purport to state objective facts but systematically fail to do so, making all positive moral assertions false.
W.D. Ross's pluralistic deontological framework distinguishing duties that hold unless overridden by stronger competing duties, requiring understanding of how moral obligations conflict.
Rawls's method of moral justification that seeks coherence between particular moral judgments and general principles through iterative revision.
The problem that factors outside an agent's control affect moral judgments of their responsibility, challenging the Kantian idea that only will determines moral worth.
The normative view that agents ought to act in their own self-interest, requiring careful distinction from psychological egoism and from altruism.
The application of ethical reasoning to biological and medical questions — including consent, end-of-life decisions, and genetic manipulation — requiring working knowledge of both science and ethics.
The question of what moral consideration is owed to non-human animals, engaging utilitarian, deontological, and relational frameworks and requiring substantive analysis.
Theories governing the fair allocation of benefits and burdens in society, encompassing Rawlsian egalitarianism, libertarianism, and sufficiency views.

L4.brief_rationale: Derek Parfit's puzzle about how policies harming future persons can be wrong when those persons would not have existed under alternative policies, challenging standard harm-based ethics.

T.M. Scanlon's theory that an action is wrong if its performance is disallowed by principles no one could reasonably reject, a sophisticated alternative to Rawlsian contractarianism and consequentialism.
The family of metaethical views (including Blackburn's quasi-realism and Gibbard's norm-expressivism) holding that moral statements express attitudes rather than describe facts.
Jonathan Dancy's view that the moral relevance of any feature of a situation is not fixed across cases, rejecting the existence of exceptionless moral principles.
The research-backed movement applying rigorous evidence and reasoning to determine how to do the most good, engaging deep questions in population ethics and global priority-setting.

Parfit's result that classical total utilitarianism implies it would be better to have a vast population with lives barely worth living than a smaller population of very happy people, driving population ethics research.
Harry Frankfurt's thought experiments designed to show that moral responsibility does not require the ability to do otherwise, challenging the principle of alternate possibilities.

The metaethical realist position associated with Richard Boyd and Nicholas Sturgeon holding that moral properties are natural, causally efficacious properties, grounding moral epistemology in a causal-historical account.
Rawls's metaethical view that moral principles are constructed through an idealized procedure of practical reason rather than discovered as pre-existing facts, articulated in his 1980 Dewey Lectures.
The problem, central to Sen and Nussbaum's capabilities approach, that oppressed persons may adjust their preferences to unjust circumstances, undermining preference-satisfaction as a welfare metric.

The systematic framework for evaluating the moral permissibility of going to war (jus ad bellum) and conduct within war (jus in bello), requiring expert-level engagement with international law and political philosophy.

The view that moral factors — including stakes and bias — can raise the epistemic standards required for knowledge or justified belief, intersecting philosophy of race, feminist epistemology, and normative epistemology.
